comments.commentBody:
The thing about the Bears-Giants matchup is that while the Giants are outdoing other teams in the base statistics, stupid mistakes and ineffectiveness in the red zone are losing games for them. The algorithm used for this blog doesn't look at mental mistakes very heavily. I think that the Giants have a decent chance at winning the game if they can pull their heads out of their collective arses.

That said, Im sitting Eli in my Fantasy squad.

The fact that a technology is available does not justified its use and the "free speech" defense in this instance is just a cynical ploy to justify a hateful act.  The Constitution guarantees free speech as a means of political expression, not as a means of personal destruction.  The students who perpetrated this act deserve expulsion and should be listed as "sex offenders" for the rest of their lives.

Wait a minute. When I was their age, any attempt to humiliate people in this fashion was based on hearsay/I saw and not viral internet postings. That really does change the playing field doesn't it? I discussed this incident with my teen and pre-teen (both of them in school environments that are supposedly liberal but also insanely competitive) We all agreed that "mind your own business" is not a bad rule to live by. And, the fact that causing somebody immense hurt like this is somehow akin to killing a person for any other reason than self-defense or defense of your loved ones.

We also wondered about the perpetrators' need for fitting in, perhaps getting the old once-over in before they were targeted themselves for being nerdy and over-achieving. Just sayin' . Kids always understand their peer group better than we can ever wish ourselves.

My heart goes out to all these kids' parents.

The tragedy of  this young man taking his own life should not be twisted into revenge against those who invaded his privacy and humiliated him. It is not plausible that he killed himself only because of the now infamous filming incident--it takes much more than that to cause a person to kill himself. This poor young man must have suffered emotionally for an extended period of time. Shall we then propose revenge against every person, in the last year, for example, who angered him, disappointed him or otherwise disturbed him?

After reading the most recent NYT article, Ravi could APPEAR as "caring and responsible" (according to his parents) and make people laugh. But when it came to a roommate -another young man sharing his very room in college, who happens to be gay -it was TOO close for Ravi. So he chose to use the gay student's public humiliation to cover up his (Ravi's) insecurities. It is a huge mistake and unfortunately, it looks like hate crime and more unfortunately, it contributed to an innocent person's death.

There should be consequences to this -because someone like Ravi couldn't make the right choice and we need to keep young people safe, and stand up for the right principle. IF we can all choose to do the right thing in this society, then sure, no law or punishment for crime is needed. But we are not there and that's why there are law and things like human rights in America.

Civility and decency need to start at the top.  When our political candidates and leaders are bashing each other and digging out dirt about others' private lives, what kind of example does it set for young people.  That said, Mr. Ravi and Ms. Wei are old enough to think about how they would feel if their private acts are broadcast over the internet, and what they did was clearly malicious and premeditated and definitely constitute bullying.  As one reader stated, bullying is not tolerated even in elementary school, these young adults ought to know better.  What they did should not simply be excused as a lapse of judgement or youthful indiscretion (which many of our leaders use to excuse their inappropriate behaviors).  Whether it is considered as hate crime, they should be punished to the maximum extent permissible by law.  A few years in prison is not too severe of a punishment considering the consequence of their actions.

One other party in this tragedy who has a role in the privacy violation legal issue is Tyler Clementi's friend in the streaming video broadcast. He must be suffering silently the pain of Tyler's death and from the embarrassment of being part of the broadcast. He is an innocent party drawn into this ugly mess. If the two culprits are persecuted by the state he will probably be dragged into the case, and again victimized as a figure in the media spectacle. Let's hope he can be shielded from further suffering.

Re: The Rutgers Tragedy

In 1983 I was a freshman at Boston University in one of the big West Campus dorms. A few weeks into my first semester my roommate wrote me a rambling coming out letter and challenged me to live up to my so called principles by remaining in the room with him and not requesting a room change. He declared that he was "coming out on the dorm floor" and wanted me to have a heads up in case I was chicken. It was 1983 and I will admit that I thought about it for a couple of hours and I worried about the consequences of living with a gay roommate. I was pissed to be put in that position. However I'm a stubborn bastard and I decided to hang in there with him. Ego is something. Implicit in my decision to stay in that room was a decision to be loyal to my roommate no matter what happened. Believe me we got to be friends, but we had conflicts just like any other freshman college roommates. But if anyone messed with him I would have fought the whole damn floor if necessary. He was MY roommate. I took a little light ribbing from some buddies in the beginning, not much, and than things just went back to normal after they saw that I was serious about staying in there. As a result I got to know what was at that time a true subculture and learned to empathize with the hundreds of gay students who I met through my roommate. Thanks to my roommate's courage (not many people were coming out than) my buddies on the floor got to know an "out" gay person. Nobody ever gave him crap at all. Not once.

My beef with this guy Ravi is that he is disloyal, cruel, and a coward. He should have requested another roommate if he had a problem living with a gay student. I can't believe that this crap is still happening and I can't believe how gutless and cruel people have become. Courage and loyalty are learned habits that have to be practiced every day. Apparently this new crop of 18 year olds could use some practice.

What in God's name is cyberbullying? Give us a legal definition of what activities are prohibited. Will we be required to get signed statements from everyone before posting a choir singing a song on Utube.  Bullying is generally not a crime now, so do we include that as  well? Since adults are involved, schoolyard bullying would not be included, or would it? What other free speech rights do you want to alter, and why do you want these changes?  How do you know in this particular case that cyberbullying forced a teenager to commit suicide?

First of all kick them out of college
they do no belong there
,they have to face the issue they are 18 years old and are adults, a prank at 16 or 12 is different than at eighteen
you have to face consequences
You should not be able to continue your life with out consequences for the HATE Crime
you just cannot expect to go your merry way
and we cannot depend on your remorse
you have to suffer either in jail,or out but college forget that
they need to follow you two for years so you do not get any breaks
Being sorry now is too late
Someone is unfairly attacked in the newspaper: is that bullying? What free speech rights do we give up to expand laws on bullying?

Human is weird. They cannot be categorized as bad nor good. True, what these kids (15-18years old still considered as kids?) have done to Tyler and Phoebe were bad, seriously bad. I have been bullied too, but not to the extent that I could kill myself to relief from it. Taking these abusers/bullies to the jail does not sounds right. It is not a good way to treat these 'kids' or for them to relearn from their mistakes. It would only give them nightmares and regrets for their whole life. I do believe they are still immature in thoughts and being silly in their teen life. Send them to some communty servieces for 2 years, for them too widen their knowleged and to know how stupid their actions were.
You would just destroy these youngsters future if you send them to the prison and claim it as an act of crime. Forgive and forget? Yes and no.
No more laws!  The 5-10 year penalty for invasion of privacy seems perfectly appropriate here.  People who drink and drive and kill people get less than that.

I am not so sure the lives of Mr. Ravi and Ms. Wei, will be terribly changed by this. They had a moment of bad judgment, and life goes on. Everyone is heaping the guilt on them, and sadly while a life is lost, no laws have been convincingly breached. Being stupid and mean is not a crime, if that were the case, a good part of the Republican party would be in jail right now.

My personal feeling is that it is outrageous to read that
"Even if the victim had been heterosexual and been able to laugh the matter off,
there is still the fact that a live sex act was broadcast without consent."

Are we now saying it's OK to be broadcast unknowingly as long as we are a
"traditional couple"? What does that imply- that a “normal” couple could have the same thing happen to them but pretend they are not violated, invaded, robbed of dignity and embarrassed for life? I believe all this analysis, justification, compartmentalizing, and trying to make whatever happens fit with our current culture is a huge reason things go wrong in the first place.

All of us learn very early in life we have choices. Remember feeling like you were “an adult”
because you were making your own choices for the first time? Now we have too much to choose from, and each decision carries the same truth:
we are the person responsible for our actions, period.
Believing that nothing matters that much, i.e., “it wouldn’t be as bad if the victims were
heterosexual”, constantly hearing "it's not personal”, and watering down the results of our actions
has created the environment we live in now, which includes suicide.

This incident leaves me feeling physically ill;
I extend my sincere sympathy to all those who knew and loved Tyler Clementi; there is
nothing that has happened here that can be justified.

As a parent, this is a heartbreaking story for me to hear.  18-year-olds are still our 'children' and I hope to God there are consequences for this ugly bullying behavior, apart from this sad story.  I have heard more acceptance about gay orientation from high school students than seems apparent among these Princeton freshmen.  Ten years ago, I overheard a middle school student respond with 'do you have a problem with that' to someone questioning his mother's sexual orientation.  My heart goes out to the family of the boy who died.  Most parents worry about high-achieving children coping with the pressure to do well, but to be subjected to this ugly cruely from a roommate--no, no, no, nobody should have to live like this in the 21st century.

First of all why would you post that! the poor kid was tramatized enough. but you dont need to tell the whole world. thats probably why he killed himself out of shame. bulling is a serious thing. and has been going on for far to long. this kid could have been someone amazing. the next Bill Gates for all we know. and someone went and made him feel so bad about him self that he didnt want to live anymore. i dont know about you but id feel really bad if i was the person who made him feel that way. thats really low. they must have some issues as well becasue they feel the need to pick on them, for goodness ssakes he was in collage. GROW UP!

It's not - or it shouldn't be - about bullying, but about the lack of respect for privacy. And not just about planting web cams, but about accessing all sorts of records, such as drivers' licenses, vehicle registrations, the Mormon Church's geneaology records, and much more, all of which should be strictly private.

A generation or two ago, Ravi & Wei's aunts or uncles could have been subjected to peer ridicule for being different. Now that minorities have all rushed to mainstream, we are witnessing minority on minority discrimination, a new pecking order. So much for the rainbow coalition!
How much more common are we subjected to being snapped or videotaped without our consent? A youth generation raised on reality entertainment viewing humans as bit players in their real world. Nothing is off limits or sacred in their self entertainment. everyone is the puch line and the butt of their comic opus.
Historically, repressive regimes have used public humiliation to shame and torture those who threaten their order. Think of the Chinese Cultural Revolution and their public shaming and denunciations. They found it effective that they didn't need to bloody their own hands, their unfortunate victims also took their own lives. Shame!

We need new laws to require YouTube and other sites that allow the uploading of video, still photos, or text containing factual statements about non-celebrities, to obtain consents from any person appearing such videos, still photos and statements. Why should these sites get rich off advertising money using information they didn't pay us for, and didn't even obtain our consent to use? Why should these sites get fat and happy on the backs of our wholesale loss of privacy?

I recently discovered a Facebook page for my (beloved) old sleep-away camp where various Facebook members had, without my knowledge or consent, uploaded photos taken of me in the 1970s when I was as young as 9 years old. My own photos were pretty tame, but it was a breach of my privacy nonetheless. And there were photos posted of other campers sharing a first kiss, mooning, streaking and so on. I'm sure no one obtained consents from those former campers any more than they'd obtained consents from me. I contacted the administrator and demanded that he remove the portions of any photos that depicted me; I'm still waiting for a result.

These were photos taken in public, and, yes, we (generally) all knew our photos were being taken, but in 1978 no one had the slightest conception that one day our images could be disseminated instantaneously worldwide, that anyone who saw the photos could instantaneously download a copy, and that therefore the images, once released, could never be erased.

Similarly, all those Yearbook sites -- include my hometown's website -- upload photos that were never intended for permanent worldwide distribution, and the consent to publication of the image was far, far more circumscribed. Why should these Yearbook sites be able to make tons of advertising money off of *our* images, which they use *without out consent*??

What, do even those of us who NEVER use Twitter or social networking sites, now have to worry about the retroactive exposure of a lifetime's worth of photos, video and words created decades ago now being uploaded to the web?

If the consent requirement has the impact of making these sites commercially untenable, so much the better.

It's so hard to deal with issues like bullying that many administrators treat as a "gray" offense, when many campuses actively discourage sexual assault and rape victims from contacting local police, preferring victims to contact campus police/officials, first. There have been cases that attracted national attention in the past ten years that highlight the difficulties of having two separate sets of "law enforcement", as well as colleges and universities wishing to exact their own punishments, penalties, and separate "hearings" when crimes occur on campus that are punishable by state or federal law. This arrangement does nothing to give students confidence that their grievances or personal safety is taken seriously by college administrators.
It's the economy stupid. America is losing it's exalted world position and competition is making people less civil. GET USED TO IT. Stop wasting money on CIVILITY PROGRAMS and create REAL JOBS.
can one trademark their likeness, so no one has a right to use it unless given ppermission?
Humiliation is the worst and most effective torture of a sensitive individual. It's time to  draw the line and prosecute cyber harassment.. The bullies and haters have thrown open Pandora's Box.

@ "For decades laws have protected adults at work and the culture at American workplaces has gone through a transformation."

Are you crazy? I was bullied in 4th-5th grade (I was a new kid who'd moved from the city to the 'burbs, and at first was perceived as culturally different), and it was no picnic. But by far the worst bullying I've experienced has been in the workplace.

Until I finally changed my career to something I loved, I worked as a lawyer, mostly in firms, and in very firm there was at least one abusive, nasty, screaming partner, or else an exploitive and/or sexually harassing partner, who made everyone miserable, and who was allowed to get away with it, while the associates and support staff were told to "let it roll off you." And the one time I worked in-house, a clique of my coworkers deliberately tried to use politics to turn me into the "odd man out," as well as subjecting me to social isolation.

As far as I can see, while *some* progress on this issue has been made in the schools -- or at least endless lip service has been paid to it -- we're still living the law of the jungle at workplace bullying. If the bully is a rainmaker or otherwise "adds value," forget about it. Just as with sexual harassment, we're going to need some well publicized law suits with large damage awards to change it.
